definition:
Let $f\colon A \longrightarrow B$ be a function, and let $U \subset A$
be a subset. The [*direct image*]{} of $U$ is the set $f(U) \subset B$
consisting of all elements of $B$ which equal $f(u)$ for some $u \in U$.

Direct images satisfy the following properties:

1.  Unions: For any collection $\{U_i\}_{i \in I}$ of subsets of $A$,
    $$f\left(\bigcup_{i \in I} U_i\right) = \bigcup_{i\in I} f(U_i).$$

2.  Intersections: For any collection $\{U_i\}_{i \in I}$ of subsets of
    $A$,
    $$f\left(\bigcap_{i \in I} U_i\right) \subset \bigcap_{i\in I} f(U_i).$$

3.  Set difference: For any $U,V \subset A$,
    $$f(V \setminus U) \supset f(V) \setminus f(U).$$ In particular, the
    complement of $U$ satisfies
    $f(U^\complement) \supset f(A) \setminus f(U)$.

4.  Subsets: If $U \subset V \subset A$, then
    $f(U) \subset f(V) \subset B$.

5.  Inverse image of a direct image: For any $U \subset A$,
    $$f^{-1}(f(U)) \supset U$$ with equality if $f$ is injective.

6.  Direct image of an inverse image: For any $V \subset B$,
    $$f(f^{-1}(V)) \subset V$$ with equality if $f$ is surjective.
